text: Just seeing this <@UJG9WTEKG>! <@UJG5B682Y> I've done this for enterprise clients and others. There are a few ways to structure that some have already mentioned. When I run this process, I interview and and flesh out responses then turn the interview into a piece. I'm kind of out of your price range, but happy to chat process and intro you to freelancers who could do good work. Also, John-Henry's (on twitter) entire set up is like this. He creates detailed briefs and then expert knows exactly what points to make, headings, subheadings, questions to answer, keywords to include etc. I dont know his rates, but can't imagine he's cheap.

elements.text: Just seeing this

I've done this for enterprise clients and others. There are a few ways to structure that some have already mentioned. When I run this process, I interview and and flesh out responses then turn the interview into a piece. I'm kind of out of your price range, but happy to chat process and intro you to freelancers who could do good work. Also, John-Henry's (on twitter) entire set up is like this. He creates detailed briefs and then expert knows exactly what points to make, headings, subheadings, questions to answer, keywords to include etc. I dont know his rates, but can't imagine he's cheap.

text:
I can introduce you to Adam Cockell

In his words:

I am a black founder of a tech startup (AI / ML) working on unconscious bias on the sourcing side of recruiting. This aspect of recruiting bias is often critically overlooked as a first step to concrete results. The narrative around black/latino hiring, especially in tech, is that qualified candidates don't exist. The real problem is that sourcers and hiring managers don't properly scope roles to determine what a good fit actually looks like, and this trickles down to later phases of the recruiting process. Done this way, job title in particular becomes the most important indicator of fitness. Diverse talent has historically been overlooked for specific titles, and this will continue to be a cycle until we address these systemic issues at the root.

I am a former director of quality engineering and principal solutions architect at bay area software companies. I have an undergraduate degree in jurisprudence, and focused on the intersection of race and law.

<https://www.linkedin.com/in/adamcockell>

elements.text:
I can introduce you to Adam Cockell

In his words:

I am a black founder of a tech startup (AI / ML) working on unconscious bias on the sourcing side of recruiting. This aspect of recruiting bias is often critically overlooked as a first step to concrete results. The narrative around black/latino hiring, especially in tech, is that qualified candidates don't exist. The real problem is that sourcers and hiring managers don't properly scope roles to determine what a good fit actually looks like, and this trickles down to later phases of the recruiting process. Done this way, job title in particular becomes the most important indicator of fitness. Diverse talent has historically been overlooked for specific titles, and this will continue to be a cycle until we address these systemic issues at the root.

I am a former director of quality engineering and principal solutions architect at bay area software companies. I have an undergraduate degree in jurisprudence, and focused on the intersection of race and law.

text: I am hoping to re-name my newsletter to something with staying power. Anyone up for sharing their favorite newsletters, titles, what stands out or resonates with you? Target audience: new and established B2B writers, sometimes B2B marketers. People who might get a good pun, but I also don't want to push it into being corny.

elements.text: I am hoping to re-name my newsletter to something with staying power. Anyone up for sharing their favorite newsletters, titles, what stands out or resonates with you? Target audience: new and established B2B writers, sometimes B2B marketers. People who might get a good pun, but I also don't want to push it into being corny.

text:
Here's what I've got as far as naming conventions so far, for context:

B2B Writing Institute (Overall Site)
Foundations of B2B Writing (Flagship Free Course)
B2B Writing Career Kickstarter (First Paid Course)
B2B Craftworks (Podcast)
The Barrel (Daily RSS Blog)

elements.text:

text: The current newsletter is called Four For Friday, but it was kind of a placeholder/descriptive title that strikes me as boring.
